questions.question_text: A company needs to create a new website for the delivery of secure content to and from specific customers. This should be accomplished without requiring the installation of any client software. Which of the following should be used in this scenario?

discussion.content: db9 to connect to the serial port on the computer, rj-45 to connect to the console port on the router

comments.content: I have seen plenty of 25 pin serial ports.

discussion.content: Serial usually refers to DB-9(RS-232) when you see Parallel connection you think DB-25

BE is the correct answer. 

this is DB-9 connector: https://www.l-com.com/frequently-asked-questions/what-is-a-db9-connector#:~:text=The%20term%20%22DB9%22%20refers%20to,(for%20the%20female%20connector).
Console cables use DB9 to Ethernet. These are the most correct answers.
Not sure why db-25 isn't a valid answer too. And why the non-plural use of "cable" when it's talking about two cables? Sloppy.

comments.content: It’s a single cable, with different connectors on either end. Where are you getting two cables from?

discussion.content: Older KVMs would use an older interface like a DB9, possibly

a DB-25 I think could technically be used, however I haven't seen a DB-25 port on anything in a long time. I doubt you would find anything other than a DB9 on any console cable (ethernet or USB). DB-25 is a legacy connector
I'm not sure if I understand the difference between B, E and D, E. Couldn't the answer really go either way?

comments.content: STP isn't immune to electromagnetic interference (EMI), but it's the best choice listed.

discussion.content: stp immune to "electricial" , rest are prone to magnetic , best choice fiber
Well, it should none of the above

comments.content:
"STP Cabling is twisted-pair cabling with additional shielding to reduce crosstalk and other forms of electromagnetic interference (EMI). Shielded Twisted-pair Cable. The outer insulating jacket contains an inner braided copper mesh to shield the pairs of twisted cables, which themselves are wrapped in foil."
STP is the answer.

discussion.content: Per the Net+ Guide, "An important area of export regulations is in the area of cryptography." Answer seems to be correct.

comments.content:
When you leave the United States, you need to know your responsibilities under export control regulations. In particular if you are traveling with your laptop or any other electronic devices these items along with the underlying technology, any data on your device, proprietary information, confidential records, and encryption software are all subject to export control regulations. Some foreign governments have regulations that permit the seizure of travelers’ computers and the review of their contents. U.S. Customs officials are also authorized to review the contents of travelers’ a laptops without probable cause and can be held until your return.

For these reasons it is recommended that you review the Global Support Services, International Data Security Guidance webpage prior to embarking on international travel with laptops, iPads and other electronic devices.
https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/export-controls/international-travel-electronic-devices-and-encryption-software/

discussion.content: I'm gonna go with A here
